New Records: Jos Buttler scored 73 runs, moving him past Eoin Morgan as England's leading run-scorer in T20I cricket with 2,468 runs.
Sam Curran bowled at a speed of 154.7 kph, reaching a record 154.7 km/h in the match.
England scored 6-179, while New Zealand scored 7-162.
Key Match Events: New Zealand dropped Jos Buttler twice, once on 8 and once on 40, giving England a crucial advantage.
Glenn Phillips scored 62 off 36 balls, a significant performance for New Zealand.
Ben Stokes fell LBW to Mitchell Ferguson for 8 and later returned after an injury to his left index finger.
Sam Curran took crucial catches, including dismissing Devon Conway and Jimmy Neesham.
Pre-Game Insights: England faced rain fears but the match proceeded with a healthy crowd of 22,547 fans.
New Zealand almost got off to a perfect start with Jos Buttler appearing to be caught, but the catch was nullified.
Post-Match Reflections: England's victory kept their hopes alive in the tournament, with the result determining their standing in the group.
Ben Stokes briefly left the field due to injury but returned, showing his resilience.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match was played at the Gabba in Brisbane, with a crowd of 22,547 fans attending.
